instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board that had liquid damage with no green light. I tracked down that <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> is missing (it starts at 1.27v and slowly increases til 1.5ish). I can't understand how the 18v gets activated from the charger, is that via the <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> line / <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>? I'm using an 85watt charger and the DC-in jack works on the donor board I have.

* Fuse F6905 is shorted just fine.
* <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> is 47Ohm (as expected)
* <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is 10Ohm(as expected)

Resistance <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> to GND starts at 8k and slowly increases until 40k or so

Thanks! Sorry if this is a noob question.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Tried known good DC in board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
No I don't have another DC in board, but I tried the same dc in board on a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A and it gives a green light.

EDIT: AHA! Looks like something is pulling the 3.2v from the charger to be 1v. I just need to find whats pulling it down.


EDIT:
I got 18v!! Just for future reference, read this on how the magsafe process works. Make sure you have 68k load resistor otherwise charger wont send out 18k.
[URL="http://www.righto.com/2013/06/teardown-and-exploration-of-magsafe.html"]http://www.righto.com/2013/06/teardo...f-magsafe.html[/URL]

Please mark this one as solved.
